Quote: They focus on the digital literacy space for learners. They value access to quality education and the rights of children with disabilities.
We center education and participation. This is often accompanied by 'co-designing' and meeting goals.
Making sure we communicate not just what we want to do but also the results of what we have achieved.
Board of trustees, directors, managers, program officers interns, program assistants.
They have a department which governs data, known as the program department technical and Data Management department fall under.
This goes through trustees before the final board of directors.
All decisions are written down. There is a handbook with clear guidelines.
Everyone in KBT goes through training on these topics [data rights, laws, etc.].
Loopholes exist when the guidelines do not fully apply to evolving tech.
Consent should be given freely, with participants knowing the potential repercussions and outcomes.
Consent is broken down into different types depending on the context of the project (e.g. participation, photos, recordings, data storage duration).
They usually get consent via a physical printed document, which they copy and give back, but are moving to digital.
Identifiable information like national IDs and contacts is not shared.
Participants are assigned anonymized numbers even internally.
Participants expect: 1) benefit, 2) results returned to them, and 3) compliance with Kenyan data laws.
Concern over 3rd party handling of data (e.g. Microsoft not meeting obligations).
Their legal department checks contracts with 3rd parties.
Parents were confused when 3rd party partners contacted them directly about children. This was resolved internally.
P1 cannot recall any internal disagreements over data, attributes this to clear guidelines.
No tensions with funders; attributed to aligning collaborations to their values from the start.
Finance, HR, technical, and program departments all have clearly defined rules and roles.
There is a program manager for specific audiences (e.g. Uganda participants, graduates).
Overall, a very formal way of working.
Open-door collaboration policy for contacting specific program managers.
Concern: How to get consent for group images? Is one person's consent enough?
Concern: Metadata how can metadata be stripped or secured to prevent misuse?
External consultant will help with licensing policies.
